natural problem: The students in Mrs. Reed's English class are reading the same $760$-page novel. Three friends, Alice, Bob and Chandra, are in the class. Alice reads a page in $20$ seconds, Bob reads a page in $45$ seconds and Chandra reads a page in $30$ seconds.   Chandra and Bob, who each have a copy of the book, decide that they can save time by `team reading' the novel. In this scheme, Chandra will read from page $1$ to a certain page and Bob will read from the next page through page $760,$ finishing the book. When they are through they will tell each other about the part they read. What is the last page that Chandra should read so that she and Bob spend the same amount of time reading the novel?
natural solution: The ratio of time it takes Bob to read a page to the time it takes Chandra to read a page is $45:30$ or $3:2,$ so Bob should read $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of pages that Chandra reads.
Divide the book into $5$ parts, each with $\frac{760}{5}=152$ pages. Chandra will read the first $3\cdot152 =\boxed{456}$ pages, while Bob reads the last $2\cdot152=304$ pages.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes book_pages alice_time bob_time chandra_time :: real
assumes h0 : "book_pages = 760"
and h1 : "alice_time = 20"
and h2 : "bob_time = 45"
and h3 : "chandra_time = 30"
and h4 : "\<exists> chandra_pages bob_pages. book_pages = chandra_pages + bob_pages \<and> chandra_pages * chandra_time = bob_pages * bob_time"
shows  "chandra_pages = 456"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The students in Mrs. Reed's English class are reading the same $760$-page novel. Three friends, Alice, Bob and Chandra, are in the class. Alice reads a page in $20$ seconds, Bob reads a page in $45$ seconds and Chandra reads a page in $30$ seconds.   Chandra and Bob, who each have a copy of the book, decide that they can save time by `team reading' the novel. In this scheme, Chandra will read from page $1$ to a certain page and Bob will read from the next page through page $760,$ finishing the book. When they are through they will tell each other about the part they read. What is the last page that Chandra should read so that she and Bob spend the same amount of time reading the novel? The final Answer is 456
 ### Proof
 The ratio of time it takes Bob to read a page to the time it takes Chandra to read a page is $45:30$ or $3:2,$ so Bob should read $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of pages that Chandra reads.
 Divide the book into $5$ parts, each with $\frac{760}{5}=152$ pages. Chandra will read the first $3\cdot152 =\boxed{456}$ pages, while Bob reads the last $2\cdot152=304$ pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes book_pages alice_time bob_time chandra_time :: real
assumes h0 : "book_pages = 760"
and h1 : "alice_time = 20"
and h2 : "bob_time = 45"
and h3 : "chandra_time = 30"
and h4 : "\<exists> chandra_pages bob_pages. book_pages = chandra_pages + bob_pages \<and> chandra_pages * chandra_time = bob_pages * bob_time"
shows  "chandra_pages = 456"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Alice, Bob, and Chandra are reading a book of 760 pages. Alice reads the book in 20 hours, Bob in 45 hours, and Chandra in 30 hours. If the time Chandra takes to read a certain number of pages is the same as the time Bob takes to read the remaining pages, how many pages does Chandra read? The final answer is 456.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes alice bob chandra :: real
assumes h0 : "alice = 20"
and h1 : "bob = 45"
and h2 : "chandra = 30"
and h3 : "\<forall> p. p >= 1 \<and> p <= 760 \<longrightarrow> chandra * p + bob * (760 - p) = chandra * 760 / 2"
shows  "chandra = 456"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The students in Mrs. Reed's English class are reading the same $760$-page novel. Three friends, Alice, Bob and Chandra, are in the class. Alice reads a page in $20$ seconds, Bob reads a page in $45$ seconds and Chandra reads a page in $30$ seconds.   Chandra and Bob, who each have a copy of the book, decide that they can save time by `team reading' the novel. In this scheme, Chandra will read from page $1$ to a certain page and Bob will read from the next page through page $760,$ finishing the book. When they are through they will tell each other about the part they read. What is the last page that Chandra should read so that she and Bob spend the same amount of time reading the novel? The final Answer is 456
 ### Proof
 The ratio of time it takes Bob to read a page to the time it takes Chandra to read a page is $45:30$ or $3:2,$ so Bob should read $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of pages that Chandra reads.
 Divide the book into $5$ parts, each with $\frac{760}{5}=152$ pages. Chandra will read the first $3\cdot152 =\boxed{456}$ pages, while Bob reads the last $2\cdot152=304$ pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes alice bob chandra :: real
assumes h0 : "alice = 20"
and h1 : "bob = 45"
and h2 : "chandra = 30"
and h3 : "\<forall> p. p >= 1 \<and> p <= 760 \<longrightarrow> chandra * p + bob * (760 - p) = chandra * 760 / 2"
shows  "chandra = 456"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Alice, Bob, and Chandra have $20, $45, and $30 respectively. For every integer $p$ between $1$ and $760$, Chandra has $p$ times her amount, and Bob has $760-p$ times his amount, such that the total amount of money is half of Chandra's amount times $760$. What is the amount that Chandra has? The final answer is $456$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes alice bob chandra :: real
assumes h0 : "alice = 20"
and h1 : "bob = 45"
and h2 : "chandra = 30"
and h3 : "chandra * x = bob * (760 - x)"
shows  "x = 456"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The students in Mrs. Reed's English class are reading the same $760$-page novel. Three friends, Alice, Bob and Chandra, are in the class. Chandra and Bob, who each have a copy of the book, decide that they can save time by `team reading' the novel. In this scheme, Chandra will read from page $1$ to a certain page and Bob will read from the next page through page $760,$ finishing the book. When they are through they will tell each other about the part they read. What is the last page that Chandra should read so that she and Bob spend the same amount of time reading the novel? The final Answer is 456
 ### Proof
 The ratio of time it takes Bob to read a page to the time it takes Chandra to read a page is $45:30$ or $3:2,$ so Bob should read $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of pages that Chandra reads.
 Divide the book into $5$ parts, each with $\frac{760}{5}=152$ pages. Chandra will read the first $3\cdot152 =\boxed{456}$ pages, while Bob reads the last $2\cdot152=304$ pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes alice bob chandra :: real
assumes h0 : "alice = 20"
and h1 : "bob = 45"
and h2 : "chandra = 30"
and h3 : "chandra * x = bob * (760 - x)"
shows  "x = 456"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Alice has $20, Bob has $45, and Chandra has $30. If Chandra's money multiplied by some number equals Bob's money times the difference between 760 and the same number, what is that number? The final answer is 456.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes alice bob chandra :: real
assumes h0 : "alice = 20"
and h1 : "bob = 45"
and h2 : "chandra = 30"
and h3 : "total_pages = 760"
and h4 : "bob_pages = total_pages - chandra_pages"
and h5 : "chandra_time = chandra * chandra_pages"
and h6 : "bob_time = bob * bob_pages"
and h7 : "chandra_time = bob_time"
shows  "chandra_pages = 456"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The students in Mrs. Reed's English class are reading the same $760$-page novel. Three friends, Alice, Bob and Chandra, are in the class. Alice reads a page in $20$ seconds, Bob reads a page in $45$ seconds and Chandra reads a page in $30$ seconds.   Chandra and Bob, who each have a copy of the book, decide that they can save time by `team reading' the novel. In this scheme, Chandra will read from page $1$ to a certain page and Bob will read from the next page through page $760,$ finishing the book. When they are through they will tell each other about the part they read. What is the last page that Chandra should read so that she and Bob spend the same amount of time reading the novel? The final Answer is 456
 ### Proof
 The ratio of time it takes Bob to read a page to the time it takes Chandra to read a page is $45:30$ or $3:2,$ so Bob should read $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of pages that Chandra reads.
 Divide the book into $5$ parts, each with $\frac{760}{5}=152$ pages. Chandra will read the first $3\cdot152 =\boxed{456}$ pages, while Bob reads the last $2\cdot152=304$ pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes alice bob chandra :: real
assumes h0 : "alice = 20"
and h1 : "bob = 45"
and h2 : "chandra = 30"
and h3 : "total_pages = 760"
and h4 : "bob_pages = total_pages - chandra_pages"
and h5 : "chandra_time = chandra * chandra_pages"
and h6 : "bob_time = bob * bob_pages"
and h7 : "chandra_time = bob_time"
shows  "chandra_pages = 456"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Alice, Bob, and Chandra are reading a book with 760 pages. Alice reads at a speed of 20 pages per hour, Bob at a speed of 45 pages per hour, and Chandra at a speed of 30 pages per hour. Bob finishes his part of the book at the same time as Chandra. If Bob reads the remaining pages after Chandra has done her part, how many pages did Chandra read? The final answer is 456.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes novel_pages :: nat and page_seconds_chandra page_seconds_bob :: real
assumes h0 : "novel_pages = 760"
and h1 : "page_seconds_chandra = 30"
and h2 : "page_seconds_bob = 45"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<and> n \<le> novel_pages \<longrightarrow> 
(page_seconds_chandra * n = page_seconds_bob * (novel_pages - n))"
shows  "n = 456"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The students in Mrs. Reed's English class are reading the same $760$-page novel. Three friends, Alice, Bob and Chandra, are in the class. Alice reads a page in $20$ seconds, Bob reads a page in $45$ seconds and Chandra reads a page in $30$ seconds.   Chandra and Bob, who each have a copy of the book, decide that they can save time by `team reading' the novel. In this scheme, Chandra will read from page $1$ to a certain page and Bob will read from the next page through page $760,$ finishing the book. When they are through they will tell each other about the part they read. What is the last page that Chandra should read so that she and Bob spend the same amount of time reading the novel? The final Answer is 456
 ### Proof
 The ratio of time it takes Bob to read a page to the time it takes Chandra to read a page is $45:30$ or $3:2,$ so Bob should read $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of pages that Chandra reads.
 Divide the book into $5$ parts, each with $\frac{760}{5}=152$ pages. Chandra will read the first $3\cdot152 =\boxed{456}$ pages, while Bob reads the last $2\cdot152=304$ pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes novel_pages :: nat and page_seconds_chandra page_seconds_bob :: real
assumes h0 : "novel_pages = 760"
and h1 : "page_seconds_chandra = 30"
and h2 : "page_seconds_bob = 45"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<and> n \<le> novel_pages \<longrightarrow> 
(page_seconds_chandra * n = page_seconds_bob * (novel_pages - n))"
shows  "n = 456"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Chandra and Bob are reading a novel together. The novel has 760 pages. Chandra reads at a speed of 30 seconds per page, and Bob reads at a speed of 45 seconds per page. They start reading at the same time but from opposite ends of the book. After a certain number of pages, they meet. How many pages did Chandra read before they met? The answer is 456 pages.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Alice Bob Chandra :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and novel :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "novel 760 = 760"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Alice x = 20 * x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. Bob x = 45 * x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. Chandra x = 30 * x"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. x \<le> 760 \<longrightarrow> Chandra x = Bob (760 - x)"
shows  "\<exists> x. x \<le> 760 \<and> Chandra x = Bob (760 - x) \<and> x = 456"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The students in Mrs. Reed's English class are reading the same $760$-page novel. Three friends, Alice, Bob and Chandra, are in the class. Alice reads a page in $20$ seconds, Bob reads a page in $45$ seconds and Chandra reads a page in $30$ seconds.   Chandra and Bob, who each have a copy of the book, decide that they can save time by `team reading' the novel. In this scheme, Chandra will read from page $1$ to a certain page and Bob will read from the next page through page $760,$ finishing the book. When they are through they will tell each other about the part they read. What is the last page that Chandra should read so that she and Bob spend the same amount of time reading the novel? The final Answer is 456
 ### Proof
 The ratio of time it takes Bob to read a page to the time it takes Chandra to read a page is $45:30$ or $3:2,$ so Bob should read $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of pages that Chandra reads.
 Divide the book into $5$ parts, each with $\frac{760}{5}=152$ pages. Chandra will read the first $3\cdot152 =\boxed{456}$ pages, while Bob reads the last $2\cdot152=304$ pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes Alice Bob Chandra :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and novel :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "novel 760 = 760"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Alice x = 20 * x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. Bob x = 45 * x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. Chandra x = 30 * x"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. x \<le> 760 \<longrightarrow> Chandra x = Bob (760 - x)"
shows  "\<exists> x. x \<le> 760 \<and> Chandra x = Bob (760 - x) \<and> x = 456"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Alice, Bob, and Chandra are reading a 760-page novel. Alice reads at a rate of 20 pages per hour, Bob reads at a rate of 45 pages per hour, and Chandra reads at a rate of 30 pages per hour. If Chandra is reading from the start of the book towards the end, and Bob starts from the end of the book and reads towards the start, at which page will they meet? The answer is at page 456.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes alice bob chandra :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. alice x = 20 * x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. bob x = 45 * x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. chandra x = 30 * x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 760"
and h4 : "\<forall> x y. chandra x = bob (760 - x)"
shows  "x = 456"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The students in Mrs. Reed's English class are reading the same $760$-page novel. Three friends, Alice, Bob and Chandra, are in the class. Alice reads a page in $20$ seconds, Bob reads a page in $45$ seconds and Chandra reads a page in $30$ seconds.   Chandra and Bob, who each have a copy of the book, decide that they can save time by `team reading' the novel. In this scheme, Chandra will read from page $1$ to a certain page and Bob will read from the next page through page $760,$ finishing the book. When they are through they will tell each other about the part they read. What is the last page that Chandra should read so that she and Bob spend the same amount of time reading the novel? The final Answer is 456
 ### Proof
 The ratio of time it takes Bob to read a page to the time it takes Chandra to read a page is $45:30$ or $3:2,$ so Bob should read $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of pages that Chandra reads.
 Divide the book into $5$ parts, each with $\frac{760}{5}=152$ pages. Chandra will read the first $3\cdot152 =\boxed{456}$ pages, while Bob reads the last $2\cdot152=304$ pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes alice bob chandra :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. alice x = 20 * x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. bob x = 45 * x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. chandra x = 30 * x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 760"
and h4 : "\<forall> x y. chandra x = bob (760 - x)"
shows  "x = 456"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Alice, Bob, and Chandra are performing tasks at different rates. Alice completes 20 tasks per hour, Bob completes 45 tasks per hour, and Chandra completes 30 tasks per hour. Given that Chandra's rate of task completion equals Bob's rate of task completion for the remaining hours in a 760-hour time frame, find the number of hours after which Chandra's and Bob's task completion rates will be equal. The final answer is 456 hours.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chandra_pages :: nat and bob_pages :: nat
assumes h0 : "chandra_pages + bob_pages = 760"
and h1 : "30 * chandra_pages = 45 * bob_pages"
shows  "chandra_pages = 456"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The students in Mrs. Reed's English class are reading the same $760$-page novel. Three friends, Alice, Bob and Chandra, are in the class. Alice reads a page in $20$ seconds, Bob reads a page in $45$ seconds and Chandra reads a page in $30$ seconds.   Chandra and Bob, who each have a copy of the book, decide that they can save time by `team reading' the novel. In this scheme, Chandra will read from page $1$ to a certain page and Bob will read from the next page through page $760,$ finishing the book. When they are through they will tell each other about the part they read. What is the last page that Chandra should read so that she and Bob spend the same amount of time reading the novel? The final Answer is 456
 ### Proof
 The ratio of time it takes Bob to read a page to the time it takes Chandra to read a page is $45:30$ or $3:2,$ so Bob should read $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of pages that Chandra reads.
 Divide the book into $5$ parts, each with $\frac{760}{5}=152$ pages. Chandra will read the first $3\cdot152 =\boxed{456}$ pages, while Bob reads the last $2\cdot152=304$ pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes chandra_pages :: nat and bob_pages :: nat
assumes h0 : "chandra_pages + bob_pages = 760"
and h1 : "30 * chandra_pages = 45 * bob_pages"
shows  "chandra_pages = 456"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Chandra and Bob together read 760 pages. If the number of pages that Chandra reads is 30 times the number of pages that Bob reads, how many pages does Chandra read? The final answer is 456 pages.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes alice bob chandra :: real
assumes h0 : "alice = 20"
and h1 : "bob = 45"
and h2 : "chandra = 30"
and h3 : "\<forall>page. page > 0 \<longrightarrow> chandra * page = bob * (760 - page)"
shows  "\<exists>page. page = 456"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The students in Mrs. Reed's English class are reading the same $760$-page novel. Three friends, Alice, Bob and Chandra, are in the class. Alice reads a page in $20$ seconds, Bob reads a page in $45$ seconds and Chandra reads a page in $30$ seconds.   Chandra and Bob, who each have a copy of the book, decide that they can save time by `team reading' the novel. In this scheme, Chandra will read from page $1$ to a certain page and Bob will read from the next page through page $760,$ finishing the book. When they are through they will tell each other about the part they read. What is the last page that Chandra should read so that she and Bob spend the same amount of time reading the novel? The final Answer is 456
 ### Proof
 The ratio of time it takes Bob to read a page to the time it takes Chandra to read a page is $45:30$ or $3:2,$ so Bob should read $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of pages that Chandra reads.
 Divide the book into $5$ parts, each with $\frac{760}{5}=152$ pages. Chandra will read the first $3\cdot152 =\boxed{456}$ pages, while Bob reads the last $2\cdot152=304$ pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes alice bob chandra :: real
assumes h0 : "alice = 20"
and h1 : "bob = 45"
and h2 : "chandra = 30"
and h3 : "\<forall>page. page > 0 \<longrightarrow> chandra * page = bob * (760 - page)"
shows  "\<exists>page. page = 456"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Alice, Bob, and Chandra are reading a 760-page book. Alice reads at a speed of 20 pages per hour, Bob reads at 45 pages per hour, and Chandra reads at 30 pages per hour. If Bob and Chandra start reading the book at the same time from opposite ends, at what page number do they meet? The answer is page 456.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: nat and r1 r2 :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 760"
and h1 : "r1 = 20"
and h2 : "r2 = 45"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> p \<longrightarrow> n * r1 = (p - n) * r2"
shows  "n = 456"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The students in Mrs. Reed's English class are reading the same $760$-page novel. Three friends, Alice, Bob and Chandra, are in the class. Alice reads a page in $20$ seconds, Bob reads a page in $45$ seconds and Chandra reads a page in $30$ seconds.   Chandra and Bob, who each have a copy of the book, decide that they can save time by `team reading' the novel. In this scheme, Chandra will read from page $1$ to a certain page and Bob will read from the next page through page $760,$ finishing the book. When they are through they will tell each other about the part they read. What is the last page that Chandra should read so that she and Bob spend the same amount of time reading the novel? The final Answer is 456
 ### Proof
 The ratio of time it takes Bob to read a page to the time it takes Chandra to read a page is $45:30$ or $3:2,$ so Bob should read $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of pages that Chandra reads.
 Divide the book into $5$ parts, each with $\frac{760}{5}=152$ pages. Chandra will read the first $3\cdot152 =\boxed{456}$ pages, while Bob reads the last $2\cdot152=304$ pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: nat and r1 r2 :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 760"
and h1 : "r1 = 20"
and h2 : "r2 = 45"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> p \<longrightarrow> n * r1 = (p - n) * r2"
shows  "n = 456"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given that $p = 760$, $r1 = 20$ and $r2 = 45$, find a value for $n$ such that $nr1 = (p - n)r2$ for all $n$ up to $p$. The final answer is $456$.
